## Description {#details}

A base class for visitors over the uses of a pointer value.

Once constructed, a user can call <code>visit</code> on a pointer value, and this will walk its uses and visit each instruction using an <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instvisitor">InstVisitor</a>. It also provides visit methods which will recurse through any pointer-to-pointer transformations such as GEPs and bitcasts.

During the visit, the current Use&#42; being visited is available to the subclass, as well as the current offset from the original base pointer if known.

The recursive visit of uses is accomplished with a worklist, so the only ordering guarantee is that an instruction is visited before any uses of it are visited. Note that this does <em>not</em> mean before any of its users are visited! This is because users can be visited multiple times due to multiple, different uses of pointers derived from the same base.

A particular <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/use">Use</a> will only be visited once, but a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/user">User</a> may be visited multiple times, once per <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/use">Use</a>. This visits may notably have different offsets.

All visit methods on the underlying <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instvisitor">InstVisitor</a> return a boolean. This return short-circuits the visit, stopping it immediately.

FIXME: Generalize this for all values rather than just instructions.

## Public Member Functions

### visitPtr() {#a764cd98e9a2d1c1fdfb40aa63ef17385}

<MemberDefinition
  template={<>template &lt;typename DerivedT&gt;</>}
  prototype={<>PtrInfo llvm::PtrUseVisitor&lt; DerivedT &gt;::visitPtr (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &amp; I)</>}
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Recursively visit the uses of the given pointer.

<SectionUser title="Returns">
An info struct about the pointer. See <code><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/detail/ptrusevisitorbase/ptrinfo">PtrInfo</a></code> for details. We may also need to process <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/argument">Argument</a> pointers, so the input uses is a common <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> type.
</SectionUser>
